DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Of Students Battle Riot Police
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of students hurling firebombs and rocks fought riot police in Seoul and two other cities today to protest the arrest of a fugitive radical student leader. Fierce fighting broke out on the streets around campuses after Im Chong-suk, 23, and five student bodyguards were overpowered and arrested by 20 plainclothes police at a Seoul university earlier in the day. Police said there had been arrests in the clashes but had no figures. At least one student suffered serious burns in a clash at Seoul's Hanyang University and was hospitalized. Im has been on the police wanted list since March with a reward equivalent to $7,400 offered for information leading to his arrest. He is head of the outlawed National Council of Student Representatives, or Chondaehyop. Police said Im would be charged with violations of the National Security Law governing sedition and communist activity. Im told reporters at police headquarters he had planned to discuss Korean unification in a scheduled television interview when he was apprehended. The interview was not held. The most serious fighting of the day was reported in the southern city of Kwangju, where about 800 students, hurling hundreds of firebombs, battled police for two hours around Chosun University. ``Release Im Chong-suk!'' the state television, KBS, quoted students as shouting as they charged about 1,000 riot police. KBS showed scenes of columns of protesters with masks and hankerchiefs over their faces attacking police, who fired tear gas. The tear gas drifted onto the Kwangju campuses of four middle and high schools in the area, forcing them to temporarily suspend classes, KBS said. About 400 students fought riot police with firebombs and rocks for an hour in front of the main gates of Hanyang University, where Im is a senior. Police hurled rocks back at the students. In the southern port city of Pusan, groups of up to 20 students stormed six regional offices of an opposition party, demanding Im's release and protesting a compromise Saturday between ruling and opposition parties aimed at ending the long dispute over corruption and misdeeds under former President Chun Doo-hwan. Students want Chun arrested and punished. Meanwhile, police detained about 120 students who staged street demonstrations near a courthouse where a woman student and a Catholic priest are on trial for making illegal trips to Communist North Korea. ``Free the flower of unification!'' and ``Abolish national security laws!'' the students shouted as they were loaded into police buses. Most were released later with warnings, police said. Inside the courtroom, Im Su-kyong, 20, was in the fourth day of her trial on charges of violating the National Security Law for visiting North Korea without government authorization. The two Ims are unrelated.
